After the secrets came out, you could feel the panic. Not just on the streets, but inside the Council — I heard Innovators even threatened to sabotage restoration if transparency failed.
That blackout when the whole city lost BCI... it felt almost like freedom, even if just for a few hours. No gatekeepers, no shadow scoring.
Maintenance crews found this basement chamber, left over from the Directorate’s early hacks. Files showed they were running their own BCI experiments. Probably what killed Halden.
I’ve seen those files. The override protocols gave the Directorate power to change scores, ghost people, even rewrite access logs.
Once I aired the findings, grassroots groups swarmed city buildings, demanding Council expulsions.
Some friends tried to warn me — even the harmonists can’t keep the peace with all this coming out. People have started working around the system, trading favors outside official eyes.
That’s the world I want: no silent levers, no blind obedience. That’s why I did this, even if it made me a dissident on record.
Still, most are scared. The Directorate’s not done. But I can’t take any more lies. I promised myself, growing up in this city, I’d be the one to crack their story open.
Feels like the first real chance we’ve had in years.
